body.p:
By default, comes with a file security mode enabled (when deployed on Tomcat). This means that it only allows the minimal file access permissions that are required for the application to function properly:
READ access to the directory where the is deployed.
READ and WRITE access to the application's working directory.
READ and WRITE access to JVM's temporary directory.

section.title: Disabling Security Mode
section.p: To disable the default security mode that only allows minimal file permissions, follow this procedure (depending on your installation method):

ol.li: Go to the installation directory of .
In the Java Options section, remove the -Djava.security.manager system property.

i.b: Linux Installer or All Platforms Kit

ol.li: Go to the installation directory of .

section.title: Enabling Security Mode
section.p: To re-enable security mode, use the following procedure (depending on your installation method):

ol.li: Go to the installation directory of .
In the Java Options section, add the -Djava.security.manager system property.

i.b: Linux Installer or All Platforms Kit

ol.li: Go to the installation directory of .

section.title: Configuring File Permissions to Custom Locations
section.p: There are cases when the needs to access files system resources, but due to security reasons, you want to prevent your users from opening them directly in the editing page using the file:// protocol.
